Again, it raises the issue that those who are subject, by virtue of a child support liability, to the taxation rigours of the Australian Taxation Office are caught but that those who happen to be a bigger company manage to escape. This particular letter reads:

I wish to voice my concern in regard to the cost of child support. It is a very big concern not only for me but all separated fathers. The government needs to consider this matter as it affects many Australian lives, and everybody, even separated fathers, should be given a fair go. As the years pass, more and more people are going to be affected by child support. It is a very important issue.

Firstly, I would like to state I have no problem in paying maintenance and, ever since separation from my family, I paid child support every week to my ex‐wife before the Child Support Agency informed me that they must become involved.

The separation from my ex‐wife was not my choice. I love my family very much and thought I would spend the rest of my life with them. It nearly destroyed me when I had to leave my two children. I worked very hard for them so we could own one of many things, a house. I walked away from my family with only my clothes and a few items valued at approximately $500. Everything else I left for my family.

At separation, my ex‐wife requested that I pay $50 a week for each of my two children. She said that this was ample. Eight months later I received a letter from the Child Support Agency stating that approximately $245 per week would be deducted from my pay. This was based on 27 per cent of my annual wage. I contacted my ex‐wife in regard to this. She stated she could not believe how much the Child Support Agency was going to deduct from my wage. She said it was way in excess of her needs. She agreed that each month, once she received the payment, she would return to me the amount in excess of the agreed $100 per week. This of course did not happen. Once my ex‐wife started receiving the payment, she would not part with any of the money.
I am left, as I am sure all separated fathers are left, with only enough money to survive. Once food, bills, work travel expenses, rent, et cetera, is taken from my wage, I am left with nothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Subsistence living.
—Yes. The letter continues:

BREAK.PARA: It is as if child support had been made a form of punishment. I have already been punished enough by having to be separated from my children. I have to start again and rebuild my life. I once again tried to buy a house, but this is impossible with the present child support laws. There is no way I can even afford to save for a deposit. I am only 29 years of age and have since met another lady whom I wish to spend the rest of my life with. She supports me financially for my entertainment and additional expenses. This deeply hurts my pride, as I am sure it would any man. We wish to marry and raise a family, but we are afraid that we will not be able to afford it. The man is the main money earner in most families.

If my ex‐wife remarries or lives in a defacto relationship, she will have the benefit of another man's wage but I am still required to pay the same amount of child support even though she and my children are being supported by another man. If my girlfriend and I were to marry and have a child, the child support reduced by a mere five per cent. I am currently working 55 hours per week as a transport manager, for which, after child support and tax is taken out, I receive $1,600 per cent calendar month. I am working extremely hard to better my career and hopefully get somewhere in life like everybody wants to do but every time I receive a pay rise or even a bonus, my child support is increased. How can I get ahead at this rate. I do not understand how the government can say that the more money I earn, the more children cost to raise.
Good point.

Child support should be a reasonable fixed amount per child. When the government pays family allowance, this is on a fixed amount per child. This rule should also apply to child support. If parents decide to send their children to private schools et cetera then such expense should be borne as to one half each by the respective parents.

I want to be able to provide a home for my children when they come to visit me. I want to be able to purchase toys, clothes and learning equipment for them but, under the present system, it is impossible without the help of a third person such as my girlfriend. I cannot even afford the petrol to pick up my children in Windsor when I have access. The relationship between myself and my ex‐wife has deteriorated which is due to the cost of child support and the fact that I cannot survive.

My ex‐wife knows I cannot afford 27 per cent of my wage but now has become solely interested in her own well‐being. My ex‐wife would have been happy with the agreed $100 per week if it had not been for the Child Support Agency stepping in. Our relationship would still be good and our children would not be affected as they are now by the deteriorated relationship. The men of Australia need your help. Everybody affected is talking about the extremely high rates payable. It has been published in newspapers articles . . .

That again emphasises the discrepancy between how we can close laws and how we can shore up loopholes for companies that are not paying tax or are attempting to avoid paying it and ordinary, average PAYE taxpayer who is caught by the system and penalised for his trouble if he does not come into it. Tax reform is a matter that has to be addressed in this country and I am glad to see the debate is widening on that of late.

It is important that measures like this address the revenue so that we can ensure that that revenue is protected from abuse by those who seek to get around the taxation laws of this country. At the same time we have to consider, in the context of a wider debate on tax reform, just where we are going in this country in relation to tax. I am very pleased that the member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) has recognised that need. It is unfortunate that he cannot carry many of his colleagues along with him in that particular enlightenment that has come upon him.

Unfortunately, yesterday's men of the opposition are not prepared to look at tax reform in the way that it should be looked at. In any tax debate in this parliament, we should be thinking about tax reform on a much broader scale. If we did have a better taxation system, I am sure that the constant amendments that need to be made to the taxation laws of this country would reduce markedly, and directly in proportion, I would have thought, to the change that is needed to ensure that taxation is fair and reasonable. It needs to cover a fair spread and it needs to cover the multinationals who quite clearly are avoiding tax, in my analyses of that article in the Business Review Weekly. This change is also addressing the areas that need to be addressed and it is looking again at the system that I referred to, the iniquitous chid support system. In general, subject to any reservations that I have on any matter that I speak on, I support these measures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank members for their contribution to this debate and I just foreshadow that, in the detail of the consideration of the bill, I will be moving some amendments. Firstly, this bill principally contains measures that inhibit certain tax avoidance practices—that is, withholding tax and the tax depreciation limit on luxury cars, which are largely uncontroversial. I note as an aside that the luxury car depreciation limit is a longstanding one that was introduced by the coalition when we were previously in government.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been some comment in the debate about the compliance costs. It is of course very difficult to improve compliance cost outcomes when introducing specific anti‐avoidance rules. Nevertheless, the government is conscious of the need to minimise compliance costs wherever possible. In this bill, for example, the tax accounting methodology relating to luxury car leases closely reflects existing financial accounting standards for finance leases with a view to minimising the compliance impact. We are certainly well aware of the need to minimise compliance costs, not only for the benefit of the small business but also for those who ultimately pay the cost which is, in many cases, the consumer.

The member for Sydney (Mr Peter Baldwin) made some comment in relation to the standard superannuation contribution limit. The member for Sydney said that the opposition would support the measure but said it demonstrated the government's double standards by imposing additional compliance costs on small business. I guess it is just another example of the confusion we have from the other side of the house; they are going to support the measure but then they go and criticise the measure notwithstanding they are supporting it.

Let me assure the committee that the government is concerned that the use of the standard contribution limit has resulted in some rorting where tax concessions were obtained by employers for contributions to a small number of employees that were well above those employees' aged based limits. While the government is always concerned about compliance costs it is not prepared to allow the rorting to continue. I think the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) also raised some issues in relation to retrospectivity and I would like to make some comments on that.

There is already an element of grandfathering in that it does not apply to payments entered into before the date of announcement. Full grandfathering would send a clear message to the scheme promoters that they can safely enter into schemes without fear of legislative response. While it is true that in 1981, part 4A did not apply to arrangements entered into before that date of normal effect, the existing, at that time, anti‐avoidance provisions of section 260 would have applied. Evidence has been obtained by the Australian Taxation Office that one scheme in particular involving royalty withholding tax was entered into immediately after royalty withholding tax was introduced in 1992, despite a clear understanding that the Australian Taxation Office would recommend to the government that the scheme was outlawed as soon as the Australian Taxation Office became aware of it.

In relation to the liability of residents for payment of avoided withholding tax and penalty, it is really impossible to recover outstanding amounts from a non‐resident. The normal withholding tax provisions provide for outstanding amounts and penalty to be paid by the payer, that is the resident as opposed to the non‐resident. I think that was one of the concerns. A right of recovery is given to the resident to obtain reimbursement from non‐resident. The schemes often involve agreement between residents and non‐residents so I trust that the member for Curtin's questions and concerns are allayed by some of those comments that I have made in relation to the concerns that he raised in the debate.

I note that the opposition is supporting the measures in this bill. I do want to thank members from both sides of the House. I think that there have been some important issues raised in relation to taxation reform and other issues relating to child support by the member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith). It has been a wide ranging debate. I think it is important that we get these measures into place and I do thank the opposition for their support.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move government amendments Nos 1 to 4:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule 2, item 3, page 12 (line 10) to page 13 (line 2), omit the item, substitute:
Insert:
(1AB) For the purposes of this Division:
interest includes an amount, other than an amount referred to in subsection 26C(1):
(a) that is in the nature of interest; or
(b) to the extent that it could reasonably be regarded as having been converted into a form that is in substitution for interest; or
(c) to the extent that it could reasonably be regarded as having been received in exchange for interest in connection with a washing arrangement.

washing arrangement means an arrangement under which the title to a security is transferred to a resident shortly before an interest payment is made where the sole or dominant purpose of the arrangement is to reduce the amount of withholding tax payable by a person.
(1AC) An example of an amount in the nature of interest is an amount representing a discount on a security.
(1AD) An example of an amount in substitution for interest is a lump sum payment made instead of payments of interest.

(1AE) For the purposes of this Division, if a lender assigns a loan, or the right to interest under a loan, any payment from the borrower to the assignee that represents an amount that would have been interest if the assignment had not taken place is taken to be a payment of interest.

(1AF) For the purposes of this Division, if a person acquires a security, or the right to interest under a security, any payment from the issuer of the security to that person that represents an amount that would have been interest if the acquisition had not taken place is taken to be a payment of interest.
(2) Schedule 5, item 12, page 31 (lines 17 and 18), omit "that is not a resident (the subsidiary )", substitute "(the subsidiary ) that is not a resident of Australia".
(3) Schedule 5, item 12, page 31 (after line 23), after paragraph (c), insert:
(ca) when the debenture is issued, the subsidiary is treated as a resident of that country for the purposes of the tax law (see subsection (9)) of the country; and
(4) Schedule 5, item 12, page 32 (after line 10), after the definition of global bond , insert:
tax law , in relation to a country other than Australia, means:
(a) if the country has federal foreign tax—the law of the country that imposes the federal foreign tax; or
(b) in any other case—the law of the country that imposes foreign tax.

I would just like to outline to the committee the detail of those amendments. The banking and finance industry and the community in general have welcomed the government's initiatives to extend the anti‐tax avoidance measures to withholding tax. However, some concern has been expressed by the banking and finance industry that the proposed definition of interest contained in the bill could be seen by some as impacting on certain financial products which are not currently subjected to withholding tax, such as interest swapping arrangements where, for example, a floating rate of interest is swapped for a fixed interest rate in order to limit exposure to fluctuations in interest rates.

In response to those concerns, the government has decided to amend the provisions so that they more accurately target certain arrangements which attempt to convert an interest income stream into another income form, which some argue is not interest or in the nature of interest. Concerns have also been expressed that the provisions, as currently drafted, may capture some legitimate trading activities, especially those occurring on the secondary markets, instead of targeting arrangements which attempt to avoid the payment of withholding tax.

Once again, in response to those concerns, the government has decided to narrow the effect of the provisions. The definition will therefore concentrate on these arrangements and ensure that the interest component of trade and securities is subjected to withholding tax, where they are sold by non‐residents to residents of Australia just before interest becomes payable in order to avoid withholding tax. These arrangements are commonly known as `washing arrangements' and are now specifically catered for in the proposed legislation.

The proposed subsection 128F(8) provides an Australian resident company with the option of raising funds free of interest withholding tax, through a non‐resident subsidiary company. Under this proposed provision, a non‐resident company can only issue debentures in a country listed in the income tax regulations.

Amendment 2, will clarify that a non‐resident subsidiary company, for the purposes of the proposed subsection 128F(8), cannot be a resident of Australia. Amendment 3 will require a non‐resident borrowing subsidiary to be resident of the country in which it issues debentures. It must be treated as a resident under the tax laws of such a country.

Amendment 4, defines the term `tax law' for the purposes of amendment 3. The interest withholding tax and related measures, paragraph 5.59, in the explanatory memorandum, will be replaced. The new paragraphs will more fully explain the need to explore the definition of the interest for the purpose of foreign bank provisions of the tax law. These amendments apply from 1 January 1996 and I present an explanatory memorandum.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The bill has been agreed to with an amendment. The question now is:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be reported to the House with amendments.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TITLE.XREF: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (ACTIVITY TEST PENALTY PERIODS) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 March, on motion by Mr Ruddock:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin, Jenny, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I understood that we had an agreement with the government that the minister at the table and I would speak on this matter briefly, given that we have come to an agreement about this legislation. I am sorry to say that that does not seem to have emerged. Nevertheless, we will keep our side of the bargain. I will keep my comments brief and would appreciate if the government speakers would do the same.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not go much for this idea that it is everybody's right to speak in a democratic parliament if the government continues to move the gag. I think we need a little bit of sensible discussion about these issues and, when we have an agreement, they should be implemented.

It is the case that Labor does not support people who cheat the social security system. As members of the government would know, when Labor was in government, we did introduce a series of measures to tighten the social security system, using a range of data matching techniques, which I might remind the government they opposed with some vehemence when they were in opposition.

It is the case that those few people that do cheat the social security system give all social security recipients a very bad name. Our side will support tight fraud and compliance controls in the social security system. It is also very important that, in any arrangements for pursuing compliance, we strike some sort of reasonable balance between being tough on fraud and compliance and also being realistic about the effects that any of these penalties might have on the individuals concerned.

It is quite clear that the original penalty regime that was announced by the coalition in the 1996 budget did not strike a reasonable balance. Quite clearly, the government has come to this view as well as a result of pressure by the opposition and a range of other community groups. Under that regime, the government proposed that people who breached the activity test by failing to attend an interview with the CES, for example, would get no payment at all for six weeks for a first breach or no payment at all for 13 weeks—that is three months—for a second or subsequent breach.

Not only Labor was concerned with these very draconian changes that were proposed by the government. We saw the welfare rights groups strongly advocating on behalf of unemployed people that these were draconian changes that would leave people without any form of support for, as I say, up to a period of three months. Welfare Rights have put forward publicly a number of case studies that showed the very practical effects of imposition of long non‐payment penalties. We are talking about eviction, people being driven to beg and steal. These are the realities of people not having any form of support for periods of two or three months.

We will be supporting the government's amendments here today because, in our view and in the government's view, these amendments do establish an activity test penalty regime which although it does still act as a significant deterrent, does not leave people without any income for long periods of time. What the new regime will do is see an 18 per cent reduction in payment for 26 weeks after a first breach. There will be a reduction of 24 per cent in payment for 26 weeks if there is a second breach—and as no doubt the government will point out, fortunately, most people only breach once—and then eight weeks non‐payment for a third or subsequent breach.

It is the case that the government has made significant concessions. I have to say it would be appropriate that for other people who are suffering, particularly as a result of last year's budget, in nursing homes and child care, maybe we could see similar sorts of concessions. Nevertheless, the government has made significant concessions in this area. In particular, we are seeing that first and second breaches now are going to be served by way of a rate reduction to their payments rather than facing a non‐payment period. The third or subsequent breaches will incur a penalty of eight weeks non-payment, not the 13 weeks that was originally announced by the government in the 1996 budget.

We support the government's proposal to see that everybody starts with a clean slate from the introduction of the new arrangements. That will see the breaches count for up to a two-year period rather than the three-year period that had been previously the case. We are supporting the government's amendments and we are pleased that they will not have the same serious effect that they would have had on unemployed people if the 1996 budget decisions had been pursued.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Tony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak in this debate on the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Activity Test Penalty Periods) Bill 1997. The particular measure that has been introduced is a responsive one. When I say `responsive', I mean it responds to consultations that have occurred since the announcement in the budget. In that budget the government announced a range of measures to tighten the administration of the activity test applying to unemployment allowances and in doing so did meet a specific coalition commitment.

SPEECH.PARA: The range of measures that were announced did receive, as has been mentioned by the minister in his second reading speech, considerable community support. That community support stems from the fact that the community has to pay to the revenue, by virtue of the taxation system, and that money is then collected and disbursed to various areas including the social security area where there is almost $1 billion a week paid out at the present time. With that sort of money involved, the collection and then the disbursement of that money, great care has to be taken to ensure that those who are receiving the benefit of taxpayer funded allowances do not abuse the system.

In a sense, in my view anyway, social security really is in the nature of a privilege. It is not a right. It is in the nature of a trust. It is a contingent right that depends on you being honest. Provided you are honest in your claim then you have met the demands of the social security legislation and also the demands of the community. Nobody in the community minds paying for those who are less well‐off. Obviously it is extremely important to ensure that those who, through no fault of their own, have fallen through the safety net and find themselves in need of support by the social security system have those needs met to the extent that the system meets those needs where all else fails.

As I said, nobody in the community minds meeting that particular need for those less fortunate. What people do mind—and I have in my electorate received many calls about this matter—is people who are abusing the system. Measures that meet the abuse of the system mean that those who do abuse the system are properly dealt with to prevent them from re‐offending. It is a fact that 89 per cent of people who breach are first-time breachers, 10 per cent area second-time breachers and only one per cent are third-time breachers.

It is my view that when one is dealing with even those sorts of statistics it is important—and those are the breaches that are identified I should say—to remember that there is a group of people out there who are prepared to repetitively abuse the system. It is more than abuse; it is fraud. When it is repetitively done, then it needs to be met with the full force of the law.

BREAK.PARA: In relation to the Department of Social Security, it is important in this area to ensure that the system that they operate in relation to breaches is a careful monitoring program. If it is not, then sometimes people are caught up in it that ought not to be caught up in it. There has been some experience of that through my electorate office.

I say this in terms of a wide-ranging comment that where the Department of Social Security does make an error and misleads a person, then it ought to take responsibility for the making of that error, just as the person who abuses the system needs to be dealt with as firmly as the law permits.

These measures before the House, I think, are a sufficient deterrent particularly when one looks at the fact that the community is still concerned to crack down on social security fraud. When it comes to, on the other side of the coin, problems in the office of the Department of Social Security, I get the impression that that office does not like to meet a case against it. It likes to try to duck and weave.

We know—and certainly I do from my experience at the bar—that people obviously do not like to meet the consequences of their action. When they have to, it is not a pleasant experience, particularly in relation to imposition on the Commonwealth charges which come under the Crimes Act and which flow from breaches of the Social Security Act and other pieces of federal legislation.

I have had a recent example where the Department of Social Security only and solely by its actions induced someone to go onto a pension in circumstances where that person did not have an entitlement. He had provided all of the documentation, but he went to a seminar and was induced to go onto a particular pension. He was told three years later that he had to pay back $36,000. Already, the Department of Social Security in its letters in relation to this matter is trying to say, `Well look, while we have made a mistake, he ought to have known anyway'. In my view that cannot be justified.

While this is a debate specifically on activity test periods, I do say that when it comes to difficulties within the department's administration, the department also has to meet its obligations to the community. If it makes a mistake, it should be first to put its hand up and say, `That was a mistake. We misled you. We are responsible for the consequences of that misleading.' Just as, on the other side of the coin, when people make not only mistakes but deliberate misrepresentations in relation to their stated position, their identity or their receipt of income from other sources, they are met with condign punishment. It is absolutely clear that anybody who breaches their obligations to the department will be charged and prosecuted. It is also in that area that I have some words for the Department of Social Security. It must be very careful—

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope they are listening.

—I hope they are listening, too. They must be careful to ensure that where they do find breaches, they have a system in place to identify the precise amount involved in the breach, because it is that amount which frequently determines whether a person will go to prison or not. I have had experience of a case where, when trying to resolve the amount outstanding—and it was on a newstart matter several years ago involving an Aboriginal person—the Department of Social Security officers came and had a conference with me and told me what the figure was. The figure changed three times.

BREAK.PARA: By the time it went to court, the matter was agreed at about $8,000, from memory, to be paid back, when it had started at somewhere around $27,000. But, extraordinarily, after the plea was taken and the particular offender was dealt with—and he did not go to prison—the department reviewed their estimate and came up with yet another figure. This is a very important matter to look at.

TALK.START.PARA: —How did they justify that?

—It was extraordinary—they tried to justify it on the basis that, now that he had been dealt with, this was a civil liability. Ultimately the thing went away, because they realised that there would be issues of estoppel involved. I am sure the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) would not want me to get into an area like that.
—You would do it very competently.

—Yes. But the fact of the matter is that, at the end of the day, it is important when we are dealing with people who are offending against this system that they are dealt with properly and that quantum of the amount that they have imposed on the Commonwealth is the predominant factor in what sentence is imposed. On the other side of the coin, it has to be realised that if that quantum is not clearly established, an unfairness could be perpetrated. So, in all of the circumstances, I just issue what I suggest is some caution to the department when it is dealing with breaches and with quantum of amounts outstanding.

BREAK.PARA: As far as the bill is concerned, I agree with the amendment; I think it is a responsive one. It gets back to what I believe is the overall philosophy of the government: that this is in the nature of a trust; people put their trust in those seeking social security to be honest and to make full disclosure; and they demand, when than honesty is not forthcoming, that the appropriate deterrent is imposed. In those circumstances, I think the government has met the needs of the community, as well as upholding the notion that those who have fallen through the safety net do warrant being treated fairly and reasonably by the system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McDougall, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Social Security Legislation Amendment (Activity Test Penalty Periods) Bill simplifies matters for both those who receive and those who administer unemployment benefits. Anything to cut through the red tape of bureaucracy has my full support. And any change this government can make to improve the lot of the unemployed members of our community and, more specifically, of my electorate of Griffith is to be applauded.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill also resolves what I believe was an unnecessary hardship imposed on defaulters. In the past, people receiving dole payments who breached their contract were deprived of payment altogether. All social security case workers I have met have expressed concern at this measure, and I do not believe that such a harsh deterrent was ever necessary.

As the intention of all our programs is to assist the unemployed out of the dole queue and back into the work force, I believe that the changes as laid down in this amendment are equitable. This amendment ensures that no-one is left without a payment, albeit one that has been reduced. Under this legislation, dole defaulters will now face an 18 per cent cut to their benefit for 26 weeks.

Another confusing aspect of the existing penalty system is the sliding scale by which the default penalty is assessed. It depends on the length of time a person has been receiving unemployment benefits. This confusion is eliminated by this bill.

The message in this amendment is clear and concise: if you do not show any interest in seeking employment, despite the best efforts of your case worker, you will suffer a reduction in your dole payment. It must be said at this point that the social security case workers and the officers of the CES are cautious in the extreme in imposing breach penalties. By the time a person has incurred a penalty, they have usually made one thing quite clear—and that is, they prefer to live on the dole rather than follow up potential employment leads.

But this government also recognises that some breaches are unavoidable. This bill ensures that breaches will only apply in cases of voluntary unemployment, or when the dole recipient has shown no intention to fulfil the employment contract due to misconduct. The breach rule will also apply to those voluntarily leaving employment or being dismissed because of misconduct. That a breach penalty is necessary is borne out by the reaction to the current system of total withdrawal of payments.

In my electorate of Griffith, three per cent of the dole payment recipients are subject to breach penalties, and only five per cent of those are second time offenders. Under this amendment, the streamlining of the activity test breach penalties also applies for those who breach a second time. In this instance, the rate reduction is a more stringent 36 per cent for 26 weeks; but I understand an amendment to be presented later today reduces this to 24 per cent. As with the first penalty, this percentage is across the board and made clear from the word go. Also the length of time the offender has been receiving payments is removed from the equation.

While this amendment ensures that unemployed people are not left without any payment at all, it sends a clear message. That message is: the dole is not a salary. We have had to acknowledge the fact that some people do not genuinely seek work. That so many have managed to adopt a lifestyle of leisure on government handouts, to me, is a tragedy. I believe that this is due in part to the welfare policy of the previous government. Was it their intention to create a society dependent on government support? Judging by the massive increases in the cost of welfare, we were all well on the way to doing just that. The resultant tragic legacy is a generation of healthy, energetic, young people who expect government support as a first resort—not when all else fails.

However, that is not a program the community can afford without sacrifice. The previous government in its role of the all caring benefactor not only sent the community broke but also fostered the attitude that welfare handouts are a right—not an assistance to get through hard times. Anyone who denies this does not spend time with young people who are unemployed, most of whom call the dole their `pay'.

A clear result of this is the lack of young people working their way through the trades. It is now literally impossible to get a small building job done in Brisbane in under 12 months. The cry from builders is that they cannot find experienced carpenters. Many other tradesmen make the same complaint.

We have to make dramatic changes to our attitudes. We have to remember that welfare is not a right; it is a sign of an economically viable country. Our common goal must be to be able to provide sustenance and accommodation for those who, through circumstances beyond their control, have met with hard times.

As a community, we now no longer applaud the fact that we are able to meet most welfare needs. Instead, we complain that welfare payments are not high enough. Of course they are not. No government handout will ever be adequate for a comfortable lifestyle. Unemployment benefits are not intended to—nor can they—replace a worker's income. Therefore, we have to improve the administration of unemployment benefits, while offering people better options.

BREAK.PARA: We must engender confidence in the young people who are energetic and who need to be in the work force gaining skills for their later life. Those who take unemployment benefits but who do not persevere in their goal to find work cannot expect the community to support them forever. But this government certainly does not like to see anyone left without a payment in their hands, which has been the case in the past.

I support this bill on the grounds that it does not leave a person without some income, and also because it simplifies the system for those on both sides of the social security counter. At the same time it sends, I believe, a very clear message—and that is: the dole is not a salary; seeking employment must be the first priority.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak today in support of the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Activity Test Penalty Periods) Bill 1997. The changes that will result from this bill, I believe, are that we will see reductions in a person's rate of allowance for first, second, third and subsequent breaches of the DSS activity test within a two-year period, as outlined earlier this morning by other members.

SPEECH.PARA: For some people these penalties may seem to be heavy-handed, but for others they might not seem to go far enough. I believe that these measures are tough but fair. Certainly, hypothetically, if I ever found myself in a position where I was unemployed and receiving income support benefits, I would be making damn sure that I did not breach my activity test responsibilities.

In this sense, I believe that this debate goes back, in part, to the need to provide disincentives for people to be stuck on unemployment queues. It also goes to the heart of a community feeling that recipients of government assistance should be prepared to help themselves, to play by the rules and to actively seek employment. Whether we like it or not, there are some people who make unemployment a way of life. Whether we like it or not, there are some people who find it easier and more comfortable to pick up a fortnightly social security payment rather than find a job. This has to change.

I recall a recent interview of the Treasurer (Mr Costello); I think it was on a Sydney talkback radio program. He was asked by one caller why unemployment payments were not equal to the minimum wages of workers. Mr Costello replied that, if that were to be the case, there would be no incentive for people to find work—and he was absolutely right. We should not be providing people with incentives to drop out of the work force. We should be framing our social security system in ways which remove the incentives for that minority of people who want to stay on the dole to be able to do so.
The Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp) and I were talking last night with

Mr Owen Jones, from the Townsville regional group apprenticeship scheme. Mr Jones has a wealth of experience in employment training, apprenticeship courses, youth training, and so on. He was saying just how essential it is to get young kids leaving school either into work programs, such as apprenticeships and traineeships, or into higher education.

Mr Jones said that the worst thing we can do is to let them get a taste of what it is like to receive a fortnightly unemployment payment for next to no effort in return. He said that, after a few weeks or months of young people effectively getting something for nothing, the government and society face an uphill battle to turn them around and to instil in them a work ethic and to impose discipline.

BREAK.PARA: This is why the government is introducing a work for the dole program. The expectation within mainstream Australia today is that, where appropriate, something should be given back to the community by the people whom the community supports when necessary. Likewise, the expectation within mainstream Australia is that, when a person breaches or breaks their activity test in relation to Department of Social Security payments, some sort of penalty should apply.

A few weeks ago, my office in Townsville was contacted by local business manager Laraine Rissel. Ms Rissel had a couple of casual kitchen‐hand job vacancies at award wages for a couple of days a week. Ms Rissel was reported in a Townsville Bulletin article as saying:
All the employees need to do is a little bit of food preparation . . . helping get chickens off rods—maybe serving somebody, washing up and wiping the floors down.
The article went on to say:
. . . only one applicant contacted her before lunch the day the advertisement appeared.
"More called after lunch and I ultimately interviewed 16 people," she said. "But none were interested."

"Reasons for refusal included not wanting to wash the floors; not wanting to wash the dishes; touching chickens made them sick; one was concerned she might break her nails; and another refused to work until 8 pm on the grounds her boyfriend might need her before then."
When Ms Rissel called my office, she was totally frustrated because she had also contacted the Townsville CES and asked them to send some people down for job interviews. No‐one showed up.

Being in receipt of unemployment benefits should not be a cakewalk for people. The incentives need to be there for people to actively go out and look for work. That people today should dismiss so easily and trivially the offer of work, as in the instance outlined by Ms Rissel in Townsville, is incredible. The changes being debated in this bill may not directly change that, but I hope that they might tighten up activity test compliance.

As the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin) said earlier, no member of any party—government, opposition or otherwise—condones the practice of social security fraud. Governments have a responsibility to prevent fraud and cheating of the system. That is why I support the changes to be implemented in this bill in this respect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lieberman, Lou, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Activity Test Penalty Periods) Bill, but I confidently predict that, if the government is supported in the Senate—and not frustrated, as too frequently happens—by minority parties and the opposition, we will soon have reforms working in our economy and in our society which are designed to improve incentive, and to overcome the mentality, which some people are inflicted with, that they have no future. These reforms are designed to create new jobs and to give people security and confidence.

SPEECH.PARA: In that context, I hope this legislation goes through quickly but, on the other hand, I believe that if the government's whole policy approach is supported, we will not need to access the legislation which I now support because fewer and fewer people will be in the mould of not wanting to work and of taking advantage of the rules.

There was a clear message from the electorate during the last election that a mandate should be given to the government that was prepared to tackle abuse of unemployment benefits. Unfortunately, a few people make it bad for many. There is no doubt about that. Let me recount a brief story. I was at a factory in Benalla, in my electorate, recently. The factory has a turnover of some 30 per cent of staff, and unfortunately many of them are at the younger end of the group. They disappear from the factory when the warmer weather arrives in the north and the winter arrives in the south. Guess where they go? They go north. This was reported to me by a reliable operator of a medium sized industry, whom I respect, and he was prepared to back it up with information.

This legislation is designed to put pressure on people who do not believe they have a responsibility to their country and who think that they can abuse it. Support for people in need and for the disadvantaged is something that we are all proud, as Australians, to help develop and to support governments to deliver.

On the other hand, there has not been enough debate in this country about the fact that all of us who are in need from time to time and who do get a helping hand also have a continuing responsibility, despite difficulties, to make a contribution ourselves in whatever way we can to ensure that the country is enhanced and problems do not get worse. But there is a group of people—a minority group—who do not accept that and who believe that they do not have to put in an effort.

There are plenty of stories of people who say that there is work out there provided that you have got enough get up and go, and that you work assiduously at it. On the other hand, I have been with families that have lost their children due to suicide, unfortunately. I am reminded of a young male person who hanged himself after a job interview—about his 150th over the previous three years—when he did not get the job. There is no doubt that there was a connection, such was his despair and despondency. We cannot cast all people who are not able to get work as people who are not out there trying.

TALK.START.PARA: —The majority are.

—The majority of people want to work, there is no doubt about that. And that is why this legislation and my support for the legislation should be seen in the context that this is a measure designed to make certain people—thankfully, a minority—face up to their responsibilities.
—Will it apply to the majority?

—The majority will not be worried about it and will support it. I honestly believe that the majority of Australians, no matter what their political colour is, support any government that is willing to try and make people realise that the taxpayer makes a big sacrifice to pay taxes to a government in order to help people in need, and we are glad to continue to do that. But we will not, and should not, tolerate, as a parliament or as a nation, people who get away with doing things that do not involve them honouring their obligations. That is simply it.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say, too, that I believe that a number of government initiatives, including the work pathway to improve the apprenticeship system and using schools to stimulate kids and to train them in their senior years as they go into year 12 in part‐apprenticeship training systems, are fantastic ideas and I am very excited about them. Thirty per cent of our kids drop out from school in years 9, 10, 11 and 12 and many of those young people become the long‐term unemployed. Some people, a minority, will be affected by this legislation. Unfortunately some of them will become part of the youth suicide statistics.

One of the problems, of course—and the government is addressing this and I hope all members will support the government on this—is that the kids are dropping out of school because of dysfunctional families, pressure, and the fact that they are not stimulated in some way by the curriculum. They do not feel that there will be a job at the end anyway, so why hang in. The government's approach is to introduce vocational training in the schools, so that kids can walk out of year 12 with a VCE certificate that says quite proudly that they are part qualified in their trade training and know that they will have a better chance of getting an apprenticeship, a trade and a skill.

From the same factory in Benalla that I referred to, I learned that they cannot get fitters and turners. This country, with 800,000 unemployed, cannot find enough skilled tradespeople. What a paradox. These are the challenges that the government faces.

In conclusion, I recently had the pleasure of spending some time with a program in Long Beach, California. It was established by the federal, state and local governments, the community and McDonnell Douglas, after McDonnell Douglas retrenched 25,000 people—a pretty disastrous situation for that community. I learned a lot from my visit and I have a lot of information available on how they tackled the problem of people being retrenched, unemployment, training, morale, physical fitness, keeping people involved, and the team approach. It is a fantastic story and I have got a lot of material which I am happy to share with members of parliament from any side and the community, and I intend to make some speeches in parliament over the next few weeks about it.

They have a sort of activity test, and I do not know whether we would approve of it or not; but let me tell you that they have just introduced some software whereby, as the person involved in the program goes from case manager to interview to training program, they have an identity card which is swiped with a barcode. That means that automatically the case manager has for retrieval on the screen all of the steps that they are taking, who they are seeing and the phone and fax numbers. When they see their case manager for a review, the case manager is up to date: he can ring the person they saw, because he has their phone and fax number and the like. It is actually a positive.

The people working in the system, on the other side of the desk, actually wear the same sort of identification, so it is not seen as, `You're one and we are the other.' They are all in it together. They also have a fitness program which impressed me greatly. All the people in the scheme actually become involved in a regular fitness program, because you cannot go out and fight for a job when you have had a kick in the guts, if you are not fit: you have to be physically fit to keep your morale up.

They do a lot of good work there, and there are some good examples that we could use. The other thing they do is head‐hunt. The Yanks head‐hunt more than we do. They actually ring successful people up from Detroit and say, `You're the best car manufacturer,'—or foreman, supervisor or whatever—`and we have got some fantastic people over here. We want to use you for six months. We have spoken to your boss and he is reluctant to let you go, but he said okay.' These people come over and they get to know the people in the program, and they actually ring their contacts across America and Canada and say, `I've got the finest people involved in your particular skills; and I believe that, with your expansion program that I know about because I am in the industry, you could fit them in. So, what about seeing them for me?'

They have also got a system where each person has their own little office with a phone. They are allowed to ring anywhere in America free of charge to arrange job interviews, and to discuss and find out how they go about things. There is a really positive attitude to helping these people. The one‐stop shop program which our government is introducing—where everybody can go in to the one place, with a case manager and the works to bring all the talent together to help people—may well become as successful as the program in America appeared to me to be. I emphasise again that I am happy to share this information with members, if they would like.

I welcome the opportunity to continue for a short time in relation to the Social Security Legislation (Activity Test Penalty Periods) Bill. We do have to look at all of these measures in the legislation in this context. Whilst, on the face of it, they appear pretty negative and can seem a bit harsh to some people, the measures should be seen in the context of everything that we can do to make people's lives better and to enhance their future and give them more opportunity.

This legislation is not in isolation from what the government thinks should happen. It is one of a whole range of things that need to be done: issues such as the pathway program, the modern apprenticeship scheme and the like—and maybe some of the Long Beach, California systems that I am speaking about. If we do all of those things well enough, there is nothing that will stop us from getting people who want to work an opportunity to work in the future. I believe that very strongly, and I continue to argue for it.

I make one final plea. The mood of the electorate is obvious: all members of parliament can read it. There is a lot of discontent and unhappiness about what is going on. I believe a lot of it is directly attributable to the way in which the Australian Senate is frustrating a government with a strong mandate to deliver its reform programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your political party pushing all the buttons?

—That is a different issue, and I would like to talk to the honourable member who interjects at another time on that. The issue of a government being elected with an overwhelming mandate to address long‐term unemployment and the deficit and to introduce long overdue micro‐economic reforms is the real point. I personally believe that those in the Senate who frustrate a government with a strong mandate will in fact be dealt with very severely by the electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is another example of that trend. We have had 13 years of a government that spent more than it earned; that put us into debt and reduced investment, confidence and incentive. We now have a government that is often being opposed, with the opposition and the minority parties in the Senate trying to stop us from doing the urgent reforms that should have been introduced 10 years ago. No‐one can tell me today that, for young kids out in the real world—some of whom are in the mould of those who have lost the incentive to work and do not think they have got any future—the poor performance of the previous government over 13 years has not made an indirect contribution towards their state of mind. Do not tell me that you do not believe that that is the case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron, Ross, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I regard those of us on this side of the House as being here today to defend the integrity of the welfare system in this country. No‐one would dispute the fact that there are individuals in the community who find themselves, for one reason or another, in a position of urgent material need. Most of us would accept that there is a legitimate and important role for the government to ensure that Australians are guaranteed a life of dignity and the opportunity to participate in the fruits of a comparatively prosperous and, in my view, very equitable society.
—You need to create some jobs.

—I note the interjection of my colleague. That is a charge I am very happy to respond to because this is the government which is actually doing something about it. This is the government which is creating jobs and has delivered to the Australian people four successive interest rates cuts. The idea of the former government was that you create jobs by issuing press releases, introducing new acronyms, creating massive government bureaucracies and rotating people through the rotating door of programs that never actually lead to a permanent job.
—You are in government now. What are you going to do?

—This government has taken the much more realistic and visionary approach of setting the macro signals of the economy in such a way that small businesses feel a level of confidence about employing people. There is the hypocrisy of the Australian Labor Party when it introduces something like the job‐destroying unfair dismissals law. There is the ACTU mentality, which is that once you get in the jobs club nobody else is allowed in. We take a different approach; we want everyone to get a job. We want any Australian to have the chance to get into that club. We want to expand the club. We want to break down the barriers to entry.
—It was a target for 2000.

—We do not want people to have to be a member of the ACTU, we do not want people to have to be some sort of compulsorily conscripted member of the trade union movement. We want to create and breathe a climate of incentive into the Australian economy.

SPEECH.PARA: I had the pleasure last night to address the 300‐odd shop retailers from Westfield Parramatta. They spoke to me about how they were fearful about taking on young Australians because they were not sure what their future sales were going to be and what the long‐term projections were. Even where demand was good for a period, they were reluctant to take people on because the legislative framework that the previous government had created represented a massive barrier to new employment, especially for young Australians. In western Sydney, we have borne the brunt of Labor's mismanagement and the exclusivist ACTU mentality of, `Me first and the rest of you can look after yourselves. Once we are in the jobs club, no‐one else can get in.' We explicitly repudiate that sort of mentality.

We are a government that has come forward and said that we are going to bite the bullet on the $100 billion worth of debts. For every $1 million of that $100 billion worth of Commonwealth debt accumulated by the previous government over its term of office, you have to visualise one of Labor's ministers wandering up to some forum and announcing a massive new government program of revolving doors, and then the dashed hopes and shattered dreams of young Australians who never actually got a job out of it.

What we are doing is recognising that governments are not omnipotent. Governments are not God. Governments do not create sustainable long‐term real jobs—the private community does. It is the mums and dads out there, running the shops, the small businesses, the service firms. The ones doing it are those who are getting up early and going to bed late trying to build a better future for Australia. It is not being done by building massive bureaucracies and gazebos and castles in the air here in Canberra; not by us featherbedding our own nests and guaranteeing our own security here, and not by us erecting more and more barriers to new employment in order to ensure our own guaranteed long‐time tenure and security.

BREAK.PARA: This government is about breathing incentive and life back into an economy which has been struggling under Labor for 13 years. That is where we come back to the subject matter of this bill. It is about preserving the fundamental integrity of the provision which governments make for those in need. And those who have the greatest ire, if you like, for welfare cheats and for fraudulence in the welfare system are not generally the rich, but those who are just a couple of income bands above the welfare recipients. They are the ones who are on $25,000, $30,000 or $35,000 a year, trying to support themselves, a family, a couple of kids, and pay off a mortgage. They are the ones who resent getting up early in the morning, commuting to work, spending all day on the shop floor, going home at the end of the week absolutely exhausted and knowing that they are only a relatively small distance ahead of others who, in a minority of cases, have made no bona fide effort to turn their own situations around.

I stress that it is a minority of cases. Nonetheless, unless you address that minority of cases, unless you can go to the Australian taxpayer, to that breadwinner earning $25,000, $30,000, $35,000 a year and trying to support a family on it, and say to him or her, `We are seeking to ensure that welfare goes to those who are genuinely in need,' then you create deep divisions within the community. In fact, unless you take the sorts of steps that we are now taking as a government, you actually create deeper and deeper divisions in the Australian community, because those in employment will begin to deeply resent those who, for one reason or another, are beneficiaries of welfare and transfer payments; and anyone who is receiving a benefit from the government will tend to get tarred with the same brush as the minority who are rorting and abusing the system.

You have to go forward to the Australian people with a sufficiently clear set of principles upon which a person receives welfare. If those principles are breached, it is an entirely moral, correct and appropriate response to breach the ongoing payment of that benefit. Unless you do it, in the long run the people who suffer the most are in fact the worthy recipients, because they are branded with the most pejorative language and lumbered with the most intense loathing from the rest of the community who feel that the payments are unjust.

I note that the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) is in the chamber. He has taken steps to ensure the integrity of the existing immigration program without which the whole program would be called into question by the population as a whole. The Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) is doing the same thing in this vital area.

There is nothing more destructive to a person's life than to actually acquiesce in their abuse of welfare. In fact, the person whose life is most badly affected is the person who accepts a very low quality of life, a very poor standard of living, but who accepts it nonetheless as a chosen lifestyle. That person has got to be, in a sense, rescued from their own indulgence. That is where governments have to ensure that when we are expending taxpayers' funds, we are doing so for a pretty compelling reason.

We have to remember that every one of the $140 billion‐odd which the Commonwealth spends has to be taken out of the private economy. To fund our annual budget of roughly $140 billion, that money has to come from somewhere. There are 2½ million people in western Sydney, many of whom are on modest incomes; but they are paying their way. They are the PAYE taxpayers who are getting slugged by us, week after week after week, and they want to be pretty sure that the money we are spending is appropriately targeted and is achieving the objectives for which it was spent. When I talk to people all around Australia they say to me, `I don't resent paying taxes. I resent waste. I do not resent people in genuine need receiving some support. I resent those who make a lifestyle of it.'

All members ought to be able, unequivocally, to support and uphold what we are doing here today. It is a moderate step, but it is nonetheless an important step. It has a practical dimension and it has a symbolic dimension. It is a long overdue reform. I note that the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone, has introduced similar provisions in the area of employment benefits. Those who are helping young people find jobs say that this has provided an excellent stimulus, an excellent prod, a useful little discipline to get people focused on the job at hand.

It was noteworthy that when we introduced higher levels of enforcement for breach in relation to unemployment benefits, a large number of people simply dropped out of receiving the dole altogether. That is a reflection of the fact that, if you are going to pay benefits to target a particular social outcome, you have to ensure that they hit the target. It is no good spraying bullets all over the place and hoping that one or two of them hit the mark.

Those bullets are the privately generated dollars of the mums and dads out there who are struggling to make ends meet. We have a grave moral and public policy obligation to ensure that those dollars go to those who are genuinely in need. That is the purpose of the bill, that is why I am supporting it, and I urge other members to do the same.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP
