The government amendments can be broadly grouped into three areas. The first, following discussions with the opposition as I have mentioned, is that changes are made by amendments 1, 6, 8 and 13 to the penalty periods applicable where a person breaches the activity test. The penalty for the second activity test breach is reduced from 36 per cent rate reduction over 26 weeks, to a rate reduction of 24 per cent.

In addition, the penalty for the third or subsequent activity test breach is reduced from 13 weeks of non‐payment to an eight‐week period of non‐payment. This is now agreed. This group of changes lessens the severity of the activity test breach penalties for second and subsequent breaches, while maintaining the broad structure and integrity of the new regime.

Second, changes are made by amendments 2 to 5 and 9 to 12 to clarify the intention of the provisions relating to the application of the activity test penalty period, whether rate reduction or non‐payment in respect of breaches that occur before a person claims an unemployment payment. The government amendments will make it clear that these provisions only apply to cases of voluntary unemployment, unemployment due to misconduct, and voluntarily leaving or being dismissed from a labour market program due to misconduct.
Third, a number of technical changes are made by amendments 7, 14 and 15 that standardise the terminology used in the new provisions and correct a minor numerical error.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The bill has been agreed to with amendments. The question now is that the bill be reported to the House with amendments.

TITLE.XREF: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 March, on motion by Mr Anderson:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Connor, Gavan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 is an omnibus bill which consists of nine schedules of amendments to a range of acts. They include the Australian Horticultural Corporation Act 1987, the Export Control Act 1982, the Farm Household Support Act 1992, the Imported Food Control Act 1992, the Moomba‐Sydney Pipeline System Sale Act 1994, the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967, the Quarantine Act 1908, the Sea Installations Act 1987 and the Social Security Act 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: I will deal with those amendments relating to the primary industries portfolio and the shadow resources and energy minister will be dealing with those relating to the resources and energy portfolio. The amendments that are being proposed in this legislation are largely non‐contentious and the opposition does not intend to oppose them.

The first amendment relates to the Australian Horticultural Corporation Act 1987. The Australian Horticultural Corporation is a statutory marketing authority which was established under the Australian Horticultural Corporation Act 1987. Since its inception, the federal government has provided annual funding of about $1.5 million to provide marketing and other support activities for Australian horticultural industries, to assist in their export promotion activities, and to get the industry focused on exports. This funding is due to run out in June 1997. There are a range of horticultural industries which participate in the Australian Horticultural Corporation by way of a statutory levy. The industries cover apples and pears, oranges, avocados, chestnuts, stone fruits, dried vine fruits and macadamias.

There have been some industry concerns expressed about the high cost of participating in the Australian Horticultural Corporation. As a result, the board of that corporation has undertaken a review of its overheads and its operations and has responded by proposing a reduction in the size of the board from nine to seven. The purpose of this particular amendment is to reduce the number of `other members' on the corporation from six to four to give effect to that situation.

I spoke yesterday in this chamber about the wine industry and the strategy vision it had developed to expand its exports over the next three decades. Of course, the horticultural industries, the exporting thrust of which the Australian Horticultural Corporation oversees, is an industry that shows enormous potential for export.

Much has been said in this House and elsewhere about the burgeoning demand for perishable food exports to Asia and the opportunities which exist for Australian horticultural produce in these growing markets. The activities of the corporation is central to and very important in improving the export performance of this industry.

However, we all know that it is not just a matter of promotion of products in these particular export markets. Australia has a lot more work to do in expanding its productive base and getting the produce that is grown in this range of industries into the export markets on time and of sufficient quality to demand a premium price. Our Achilles heel at the moment is the freight task, particularly airfreight. I just mention, Mr Deputy Speaker, that I was in Tasmania only last Saturday speaking to horticultural producers about the opportunities that exist for the export of produce from your state and other areas.

I raised with them a particular proposal that is very important to the Geelong region, and that is the development of the Avalon Airport as a dedicated airfreight facility for the export of perishable products, including horticultural products to Asia that I have just mentioned. Avalon Airport, as you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, is a former military airfield that the government has recently leased to Foxerco, a joint venture between the trucking magnate Lindsay Fox and Serco.

The airport lies at the juxtaposition of several major transport assets in the region—the Princes Highway, the national standard gauge and the port of Geelong. There are very few places on the face of the earth that have this juxtaposition of such transport assets offering the opportunity for large scale airfreighting of horticultural and other produce out of Australia into these burgeoning markets.

There has been a push in the Geelong area, and elsewhere, for this facility to become a dedicated airfreight facility for the export of horticultural and other products. We seem to be getting somewhere in that task. The company which now leases the airport has committed $2½ million to materials handling equipment to handle horticultural and other produce. We expect the facility to be able to handle airfreight out of there in the not too distant future.

To supply a significant operation one needs a very productive hinterland. That whole proposal is based on drawing produce not only from the state of Tasmania but from Victoria, the Riverina area and South Australia. I mention this proposal because if this dedicated airfreight facility for the export of horticultural products, and other floricultural and aquaculture products, were to get under way the generation of export income and employment would be quite enormous. I guess in the midst of that will be the Australian Horticultural Corporation—trimmed down, in line with the demands of industry—promoting exports.

Another particular amendment in this legislation relates to the Export Control Act 1982. The proposed amendments to section 23 of the act will extend the export certification arrangements that currently exist between AQIS and registered export establishments for Australia's fish and dairy industries to meat export establishments. We have seen rather substantial developments in information technology over the past decade, and accompanying that have been rapid advances in electronic transmission systems. The amendments being proposed will enable registered processing establishments, brokers, exporters, cold store operators and on‐site AQIS officers to facilitate the issuance of export permits.

It is part of that streamlining of the bureaucratic task that accompanies our export effort. Of course, we need to regulate this area but we have to, as a government, determine that we will keep pace with developments that are occurring in information technology in our electronic transfer system. That particular amendment gives effect to that.

The amendments to the Farm Household Support Act 1992 and the Social Security Act 1991 provide mechanisms for overpayments of drought relief payments to be recovered. The Farm Household Support Act provides for overpayments of drought relief payments to be recovered as a debt due to the Commonwealth but it does not particularly specify the means by which these debts may be recovered. These amendments will provide the mechanisms by which drought relief payment debts can be recovered. That will ensure that there is equity and uniformity with the recovery payments that exist in other areas of social security payments. Of course, the amendments to the Social Security Act 1991 mirror the provisions for overpayment recovery in respect of the Farm (Household Support) Act 1992.

Another particular act that is the subject of amendments under the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill that is before the House is the Imported Food Control Act 1992. The amendment that has been proposed for the Imported Food Control Act 1992 provides power to make exemptions from all of the provisions of the act for certain New Zealand food and that regulations specify the `food of a kind' to which exemption applies. This proposed amendment will not affect Australia's quarantine requirements. This particular amendment relates to the Trans-Tasman Mutual Recognition Bill, which was anticipated to have overriding provision in respect of the application of the Imported Food Control Act 1992 to food imported from New Zealand.

BREAK.PARA: The final matter that I wish to deal with in my introductory remarks relates to the Quarantine Act 1908. The amendments being proposed to the legislation are intended to clarify and confirm the legislative authority for quarantine policy shifts that reflect areas of heightened quarantine interest such as the discharge of waste water from vessels. These amendments are being proposed following a review of the quarantine proclamations and quarantine regulations.

These are all fairly non‐contentious amendments—if I can say that, Mr Deputy Speaker—being proposed to the Primary Industries and Energy Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997. The opposition does not intend to oppose the amendments that are being proposed by the government. My esteemed colleague the honourable member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) will be taking up those particular amendments which relate to the resources and energy portfolio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew, Neil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have an opportunity to participate in this debate, and to follow my good friend and colleague the member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) who, I must say, gave a very bipartisan summary of the state of this particular legislation. The member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) has said it is in his nature, and I am happy to pick that point up. I want to further expand on that by saying that it struck me as I sat here that I could in fact—it would be more convenient for Hansard if I could do this—ask the member for Corio for his speech and merely read it as my speech will only be reflecting the same sentiments as his. This has been quite a bipartisan approach. The member for Corio said at one stage, and I wrote it down, `We will have to, as a government . . . ' I thought that was obviously a freudian slip, which I can understand, but it was giving an even more bipartisan shine to the legislation before the House.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of what I am saying therefore, Mr Deputy Speaker, will be repetitious, although I must say that I had not had the privilege of being in your electorate last week, so I would have had to eliminate that part of the member for Corio's speech. I am, of course, happy to be in your electorate at any time, if only to help win for you those votes that the member for Corio may have lost you. Only time will tell.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is very unkind.

—Not at all, member for Corio. In fact, it could be reflecting on my own capacity to win votes for the Deputy Speaker. The legislation before the House, as the member for Corio has said, comprises a number of relatively minor changes to a range of acts. The first of those changes is to the Australian Horticultural Corporation Act 1987. As the member for Corio has already revealed to the House, the corporation is currently supported by the apple, pear, orange, nursery, fresh stone fruit, avocado, chestnut, macadamia and dried vine fruits industries.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the corporation recognises that a number of those industries that are signatories to it are unhappy with the cost of its overheads. As a result, the corporation has taken the quite responsible decision to prune its activities, so that in future it will comprise the chair, a government member, the managing director and, in place of the six additional members, it will have four additional members, with the act being further amended to ensure that a quorum will be made up of four people.

In many ways the corporation is mirroring what the government has been endeavouring to do—that is, cut overheads to the point at which only key performance people are left. I will acknowledge, in the spirit that was being echoed in this chamber earlier, that cutting overheads clearly means it is more difficult to immediately prune unemployment, because additional people are made unemployed. It hurts, but the government knows that if you are serious about unemployment, then you need a productive Australian base and you need people employed in productive industries. And what the government is about is fostering as many productive industries as possible.

The legislation before the House also deals with the Export Control Act and allows the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service to amend the way in which it goes about its quarantine inspection so that suitably qualified people can be authorised to undertake inspection on behalf of AQIS. What is happening—as you would be aware in your electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker, and as all members in the chamber currently would be aware—is that there is an increasing emphasis on exporters assuming more and more responsibility for the quality control of their products. Here we have a case where the minister is rightly saying, `Let's not reduce AQIS's control, but reduce AQIS's immediate involvement and so let our exporters take more responsibility.'

I was pleased to see this amendment, because I have had an experience over the last month with a major new exporter of horticultural product in my electorate who was being adversely affected and frustrated by the actions of AQIS. In the town of Renmark, the Almondco group have come together as a conglomerate of almond processors in a magnificent new factory, dominating the almond processing industry in South Australia. This is of particular significance both from an export point of view and an AQIS point of view in terms of this debate.

For many years Australians have had to import almonds simply because Australian almond production did not match the consumption. There has now been a dramatic growth in irrigated almond orchards and a dramatic growth in the range of varieties available to growers. So we are now at the point where we not only have a viable Australian almond industry that, without any protection, has to meet competition from modern producers, such as those in California; but, furthermore, we have an almond industry with an eye to the export market. Almondco came to me because they saw export markets they could service. They were anxious to get into those markets. They had signed up contracts for those markets—and I will reveal that in a moment. Then they found themselves frustrated because of the way in which AQIS had demanded standards that were beyond the pale.

No‐one quibbles, of course, with the need for Australian export standards to be top quality; no‐one quibbles with the need for us to export nothing that puts our reputation at risk. But I know Almondco and I know their almond product. Theirs is the most modern factory in Australia and they are taking their almonds off huge, professionally run orchards. But they were being frustrated by AQIS's insistence that the i's be dotted and the t's be crossed, and they came to me to seek some relief.

It is to the minister's credit that Almondco now have their approval and that the AQIS officers who were causing the frustration have been appropriately dealt with. The frustration was that Almondco were seeking, out of a 5,000 tonne crop valued at $40 million—and this is just one South Australian horticultural processor—to capture export opportunities which would take up to 3,500 tonnes of that crop, or an export potential of something like $28 million. It was something that the nation could not afford to lose and something that AQIS should have been facilitating, not frustrating.

Obviously AQIS had a job to do. No‐one, as I said earlier, would suggest otherwise. But their task was to see themselves as Australians developing an Australian export market in cooperation with Almondco, not as public servants seeking to frustrate what Almondco were endeavouring to do. Let me illustrate that for just a moment. A letter from Almondco says:
We were informed that they—
that is AQIS—
will also not sign off without an Import Licence Number for shipments to Iran, Korea, Japan and India, as almonds are prohibited goods for import in those countries without a licence.
The Almondco manager says:

I was reluctant to contact our customers as it is a falling market at present and I did not wish to give them any reason to cancel their contracts with us. However, I did receive replies, by fax, from customers in Japan and Korea who informed us that Import Licence is not required.
I have with me at present our new customer from India, who informed me verbally, and who will confirm by fax that Import Licensing for almonds was discontinued by India three or four years ago.

Also, I contacted some business associates in Melbourne and Sydney who informed me that AQIS inspectors will sign Phytosanitary Certificates in their states if the words `Not Sighted' are inserted in the Import Permit section of the Certificate.

This was just a further frustration that the company was facing on a matter of AQIS being unnecessarily pedantic, a matter that subsequently has been cleared up and is addressed by this legislation, as the minister points to the fact that it should be possible for responsible companies and responsible exporters to accept the consequences for maintaining their own standard quality control measures.

As has been emphasised by the member for Corio (Mr O'Connor), among those Australian primary industries most likely to help us address our balance of payments deficit, horticulture has to be prominent. What is most needed for horticulture to succeed is increased market access.

Let me illustrate what has happened in recent times with market access that will be facilitated by an AQIS body trying to develop export markets and by the Australian horticulture corporation recognising its lean and mean role in helping horticultural producers to develop these markets as well.Over the last few months the first deliveries of Australian potatoes and carrots entered South Korea. For the first time, Australian stone fruit has been exported to the Taiwanese market. Taiwan is phasing out discrimination against Australian beef quotas and has doubled Australia's apple quota, a situation that we hope is not frustrated by the recent speculation about fire blight. Australian fruit juice, milk powder, cheese and vegemite—that might be drawing rather a long horticultural bow—are on the shelves in Sri Lanka.

This additional market access is possible because of our adherence, as we all know, to the uncomfortable rules of the World Trade Organisation. Those who, in the present climate, have been pleading for tariff protection for any industries in Australia put at risk the market access we have gained for horticultural products and for a range of manufacturing products as a result of our adherence to the WTO. I cannot sufficiently stress, politically uncomfortable as it is, the importance to Australia's export performance of a lean and mean AHC, of better AQIS standards, and of our adherence to the regulations that we are forced to abide under the World Trade Organisation.

Basically, uncomfortable as it is, the bottom line is that we only produce four per cent of the world's wheat production, three per cent of the world's cotton crop, four per cent of the world's sugar production, and 0.3 per cent of the world's rice production. We have no leverage in terms of overseas markets. The only leverage we can gain, we have gained through the WTO, and that has given increased market penetration for a range of horticultural products.

Let me conclude on this note: as many of you are aware, prior to entering the parliament, and still today, I have an interest in the citrus industry. Much is made of the collapse of the citrus industry as a result of the import of Brazilian orange juice. Much too little is made of the success that the citrus industry is now enjoying in whole fruit in cartons: navel oranges are going to North America; lemons are going to Japan, and mandarins are finding their way into Asia as a result of our adherence to the world trade rules which have given us additional market access. The Americans endeavoured to frustrate that market access. They were taken to court under the World Trade Organisation rules and obliged to allow Australian navel producers in.

The bottom line remains. There is more for us to win than to lose under our WTO provisions. Adherence to WTO provisions, a leaner and meaner AHC, and greater flexibility in the way in which we go about our quarantine inspection—as recommended in the Nairn report and covered in this legislation—will spell a better future for Australian horticulture. I support the legislation before the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As indicated by the member for Corio (Mr O'Connor), I propose to make some remarks so far as the opposition is concerned in respect of schedules 5, 6 and 8 of the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997. Consistent with the tone introduced by the member for Corio and taken up by the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), I am pleased to advise the committee and the honourable member for Wakefield that the opposition has no difficulty with any of the amendments proposed in schedules 5, 6 and 8. Of course, I deal with those in my capacity as shadow minister for resources and energy. My colleague, the member for Corio, dealt with the other schedules in his capacity as Parliamentary Secretary to the Leader of the Opposition and to the shadow minister for primary industries and energy.

SPEECH.PARA: Very briefly, schedule 5 deals with the Moomba‐Sydney Pipeline System Sale Act of 1994. These are, without need for further ado, technical amendments to tidy up the sale of that pipeline. Schedules 6 and 8 deal with the amendments to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967. The amendments to schedule 8 of the Sea Installations Act 1987 are consequential amendments upon those amendments to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967.

I would like to make some remarks in respect of that schedule but, bearing in mind that we close at 1 o'clock, I will curtail my remarks at about 12.45 p.m. to enable the honourable member for Calare (Mr Andren) to make his contribution as well.
Schedule 6 deals with the submerged lands act. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) in his second reading speech when he introduced this bill, said:
This will facilitate projects such as the proposed gas pipeline from Papua New Guinea to north Queensland, and the proposed gas pipeline from the Timor Gap zone of cooperation to Darwin.

That was a reference to the change which this amendment makes. It amends the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act so that it has the effect that petroleum pipelines in the Australian continental shelf that carry petroleum from a source outside Commonwealth waters will be covered by the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act and, as a consequence, by our petroleum regulatory regime.

In a sense, this is a technical oversight: it was not envisaged in the 1960s that we would bring gas to mainland Australia from outside of Commonwealth waters. Of course, it was envisaged that gas would be brought from offshore, as is done; but this enables Australia's petroleum pipeline regime under the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act to cover gas which emanates from outside of Commonwealth waters.

In his second reading speech, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy referred in very short terms to two pipelines: the proposed gas pipeline from Papua New Guinea to north Queensland, and the proposed pipeline from the Timor Gap zone of cooperation to Darwin. These are both very exciting prospects for Australia: for Queensland on the one hand, and for the Northern Territory on the other. It is worth making a few remarks about those.

The pipeline from Papua New Guinea to Queensland is proposed to draw natural gas by pipeline from the highlands of Papua New Guinea to the coast of Papua New Guinea and across the Torres Strait, and from Cape York down to Townsville or Gladstone. Why is this an important proposal or prospect? It is important because it further enhances both the prospect of bringing the cost of energy down and the prospect of downstream processing so far as our minerals and resources industries are concerned.

There is an element of chicken and egg here. If the pipeline goes to Gladstone, Comalco's alumina refinery at Gladstone may go ahead. If, on the other hand, Comalco's alumina refinery in Gladstone goes ahead, the pipeline proponents will have some confidence that the required volume of gas will warrant the capital expenditure! The prospect of cheaper gas is, of course, important for the Korea Zinc smelter in Townsville. So far as the alumina refinery in Gladstone is concerned, from a Queensland point of view, it is the case that bauxite will be shipped from Weipa to Gladstone for that purpose. This has the potential to create further downstream processing in Queensland. It will also bring the capacity for lateral pipelines to go into the centre of Queensland and further accelerate the competitive gas environment in Queensland.

We have had a spirit of bipartisanship here this morning, and so I will only make my next comment in passing. It is, of course, unfortunate that, in another area, so far as infrastructure borrowings are concerned, the government decision that was made in the Budget to exclude projects other than road and rail will, of course, have the effect that the Chevron proposal for a billion odd dollar pipeline project from Papua New Guinea to Gladstone will not fall for consideration so far as incentive for private investment in that project is concerned.

The second reference that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy made in his speech was to the drawing of gas from the zone of cooperation to Darwin. This is, of course, a reference to drawing gas from the Bayu‐Undan gas field in the zone of cooperation to Darwin. It is the subject of a proposed or possible liquid natural gas project, drawing gas from that field. In the short time available to me, without impinging upon the time available to the member for Calare, I will make some brief comment about Australia's natural gas industry.

Australia's natural gas industry is, at the moment, entirely contained within the North West Shelf project of Western Australia. That is operated by Woodside and is a project of six joint venture partners. The project exports 7½ million tonnes of liquefied natural gas to Japan each year—some 131 cargoes—and also has a capacity for about six or seven spot cargoes per year to different destinations. That is a substantial export earner for Australia and it is a project which, it is true to say, has had bipartisan support from this parliament since its conception in the 1970s and its inception in the 1980s.

It has been contemplated by the joint venture partners to expand the capacity of that project to effectively double that capacity. At the same time there are two or three other possible liquefied natural gas projects, one of which relates to the Bayu-Undan field in the zone of cooperation which is, of course, the relevance of this amendment.

BREAK.PARA: There is the possible Wapet proposal in the Gorgon field which is to the south of the North West Shelf, the Griffin-Rankin field and the joint venture partners liquefied natural gas project at the Burrup Peninsula. The Wapet possibility is to have a liquefied natural gas project coming from the Gorgon field. The Gorgon field is in about 200 metres of water. There is an adjoining field called the Chrysaor field which is in deeper water, slightly to the north‐east. That project, if it gets up and running, has the potential to equal the current capacity of the North West Shelf venture itself.

Recently, Mr Deputy Speaker, you may have noticed an announcement by Woodside and Shell. Shell, of course, is one of those players who happens to be a joint venture partner and also a member of the Wapet consortium. The announcement was that Woodside and Shell would conduct a feasibility study on a liquefied natural gas plant going to the Northern Territory, drawing gas from fields slightly to the east of the zone of cooperation. That project has the same potential capacity as the North West Shelf joint venture partners project.

The Bayu-Undan project is under consideration by BHP Petroleum and Phillips, an American petroleum company. There is the prospect of drawing gas from the Bayu-Undan field in the zone of cooperation to a land based liquefied natural gas plant in Darwin or a possible offshore liquefied natural gas plant. That is the subject of some consideration between those consortium partners and it is no secret that there is some modest arguments between the partners about which is the best technology and which is the best location.

When you add all those together there it is a lot of gas and a lot of potential. It will be interesting and exciting to see which of them come off. It may well be that some do not all come off, but I think there is a healthy potential for at least two big projects in addition to the North West Shelf.

Be that as it may, a very modest amendment contained in this Bill does carry with it very significant and further exciting prospects for Australia in the liquefied natural gas industry. There are further prospects of trebling—as the Gas Association's gas supply and demand study showed this week—our liquefied natural gas exports from 7½ million tonnes to 21‐odd million tonnes in the course of the next 10 to 15 years.

This is an industry which, as I said earlier, on both sides of this parliament for many years there has been bipartisan support. That bipartisan support continues and it is reflected by a modest amendment which, in the fullness of time, may well see the prospect of a pipeline from Papua New Guinea to Gladstone and the great assistance that will bring, and a liquefied natural gas project from the Bayu-Undan field to Northern Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andren, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) for tailoring his comments to enable me to make this contribution to the debate on the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997. The amendments contained in this bill to the Farm Household Support Act and Social Security Act provide a range of measures for recovery of drought relief overpayments. That is one set of amendments I particularly wish to speak on, along with the amendments to the Quarantine Act and Imported Food Control Act which provide the necessary powers to make exemptions for certain New Zealand food.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me address these amendments first in the context of the current debate over the importation of New Zealand apples. These amendments, quite rightly, ensure that the scope of the Quarantine Act, first drawn up in 1908, fully reflect matters of quarantine interest including introduction, establishment and spread of disease or pests affecting human beings, animals or plants.

BREAK.PARA: It is indeed ironic that here we are debating a bill that empowers the Director of Quarantine to apply conditions to the movement of imported goods from one area of Australia to another, where permission for importing can be revoked, where we are finetuning the definition of the goods, including mail, in which illegal material can be secreted into the country, and we are debating it a time when a huge question mark hangs over the manner in which fire blight has apparently eluded our quarantine system and entered Australia, to be discovered by New Zealand scientists in the Botanic Gardens in Melbourne and in Adelaide.

The recent discovery of suspected fire blight infestations in Melbourne and Adelaide really stretches our trust of our Tasman neighbours. How was it that within a matter of days after AQIS issued a draft set of recommendations declining to allow New Zealand apples into the country because of the risk of infection to our product had not yet been ruled out, these two discoveries were made so coincidentally.

Like several other members in this House who have taken a keen interest in the issue, particularly the honourable members for Murray (Mrs Stone), Lyons (Mr Adams) and Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell), I have listened closely to this debate and taken on board all the evidence, especially the expert evidence provided by scientists and producers brought to this country, in particular from the United States where fire blight has had such a devastating impact.

I particularly remember attending one meeting of anxious fruit growers as Nashdale near Orange on the night President Clinton was here in Canberra, a meeting where one of the President's countrymen outlined to orange growers the devastating effect fire blight had on his orchard operations. The verdict on the New Zealand research from the experts at this meeting was highly sceptical, to say the least. The New Zealand scientists were wanting us to believe that something like 10,000 cells of the erwinia bacteria were needed to cause any spread of the disease, compared to the figure of as low as 10 cells in other scientific papers prepared as long ago as the 1930s and consistently backed up over the years.

The New Zealand industry was quite understandably upset by the continuing refusal, at least in draft recommendations, to allow New Zealand apples into Australia. But that is New Zealand's problem, not ours. Something that is our problem is the Ovine Johnes disease that now infects about 150 properties throughout the Central Tablelands of New South Wales. There has been little denial of that. It came in most probably on the carpet sheep, the Tukidales, imported from New Zealand about 20 years ago. Our quarantine system let us down then. We must not allow that to happen again with fire blight.

So how strange it was that the discovery of fire blight in Melbourne and Adelaide was by New Zealand scientists. They just happened upon two clusters of mainly cotoneasters in both gardens—same plant, same sort of infestation, both in Botanic Gardens, but in two separate cities.

The New Zealand Agriculture Minister, Lockwood Smith, has apologised for the actions of the New Zealand scientists who took the clippings from the gardens for testing. He promised such a customs breach would not occur again. Well, the very same scientist, hardly chastened by this nudge‐nudge dressing‐down from his minister, has now come forward with data from a new study which—surprise, surprise—concludes that mature fruit trees do not transmit fire blight. New Zealand Hortsearch and its principal scientist, Chris Hale, who discovered the fire blight infected cotoneasters in Melbourne, say the study clears apples and pears of being a fire blight risk. He says it is a joint study with the US Department of Agriculture and that, by accepting the report's conclusions, Australia could solve the woes of South Australian apple and pear growers whose fruit has been banned in other states. And those of Victorian growers too, I might add.

This sounds like some form of blackmail. The main chamber earlier this week heard the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) answer my question on this issue. He stressed that Australia is seeking expert guidance from German scientists in an attempt to find out the true strain. There is no confirmation yet, whatever New Zealand might want the world to think.

While only 15 to 20 per cent of Australia's annual crop is exported as fresh fruit, there is enormous potential for this figure to increase rapidly in coming years. The plans to export fresh produce out of Avalon and hopefully out of Parkes and other places, such as Cairns and Darwin, to South‐East Asia show the freshest and cleanest produce in the world is poised to take on the world. It would be in the interests of competitors to ensure that we cannot take advantage of the disease‐free status we now enjoy through a tough quarantine regime that has unfortunately been eroded in recent years at both federal and state level, but, thanks to this government's latest budget, will now receive a vital injection of funding to provide close to the sort of surveillance we need.

How ironic that just as the infected cotoneasters were found in Melbourne, Australian producers were meeting Japanese authorities to discuss the export of fuji apples to Japan. Approval was likely in the coming few months but now the fireblight scare. What has been the cost of the exercise? Sales of Australian apples and pears have dropped dramatically. Apple and pear orders out of Victoria plummeted 40 per cent in 24 hours. Apart from fresh fruit exports, Australia is also one of the largest exporters of canned pears; 39 per cent of the market. So we can see the beginnings of the sort of devastation that this scare has created. Although the Japanese insist it is only until the current survey is completed, it is too late to allow the export of the new Tasmanian harvest.

For apple growers around Australia this could not have come at a worse time. Growers in the Orange district have been struggling for years with successive seasons of crops damaged and destroyed by drought and hailstones. This year's crop is one of the best in recent times. The quality is first class, unfortunately the prices are at disastrous levels. Growers need to make $20 a case to make a reasonable profit and it is sitting at about $8 a case at the moment.

The irony of the amendments to the Export Control Act, Imported Food Act and Quarantine Act is dramatically underlined in the context of this fireblight debate. Here we are excluding food imported from New Zealand from the application of the act when our New Zealand neighbours are doing their level best to shaft our clean green image. Here we are easing trade restrictions by providing for new electronic data transfer. Here we are exempting certain foods imported from New Zealand to allow us to meet our obligations under the Trans‐Tasman Mutual Recognition Agreement, where food standards and food safety issues are considered equivalent, and here we have the New Zealanders attempting to argue that our apple and pear industries should also be regarded as equivalent. How? By us accepting that fireblight is common to both countries that is how. We are not going to fall for that. We have learned a lesson, I hope, from the ovine Johnes disease. We must fight every inch of the way to maintain and enhance our quarantine standards and not fall for the argument that a prerequisite for free trade is that the level playing field will be infected with every disease under the sun.

I was going to say something on the Social Security Amendment Act but I notice that the member for Lyons is here. All I will say on that act, and I will point this out in my budget speech, I hope next week, is that there are farmers out there who desperately need the sort of flexibility that is in that legislation for people to have their situations regarded with some sympathy. There are many out there who are in the middle of another drought. They are out of exceptional circumstances but are now faced with up to 12½ per cent interest on their overdrafts from the banks. They need very sympathetic treatment in relation to the flexibility in those amendments. I will leave it at that in the interests of letting the member for Lyons have a say. I certainly commend these amendments to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mr ADAMS

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a few comments on this bill which contains amendments to a number of acts, including the Australian Horticulture Corporation Act, the Export Control Act, the Farm Household Act and the Imported Food Control Act, to name a few. I will restrict most of my comments to the Quarantine Act 1908. The amendments proposed are intended to clarify and confirm legislative authority for quarantine policy shifts that reflect areas of heightened quarantine interest. It is a pretty interesting time for that to come before the House. The sorts of things that the bill will cover include the discharge of ballast water, which is a big concern to us in Tasmania. Over the last few years quarantine has been reviewed by the body which is charged with implementing our quarantine regulations.

SPEECH.PARA: It is also recognised within the Nairn report that to achieve the objects of quarantine in Australia, in the context of pressures from world trade, tourism and our international obligations, it is necessary to engage industry, government and the general public in a partnership approach to quarantine. It also recognised that it is vital that quarantine policies have account of the impact on the natural environment that some of those policy decisions may have. I can only say that in Tasmania we have had enormous problems with ballast water bringing in all sorts of unwanted pests. These pests have flourished in Tasmanian waters because there is little there that competes with them.

Starfish are now in and around the port of Hobart, in plague proportions. It is becoming a local sport to see how many starfish you can pick up on the harbour bottom in a single dive. They are having a serious effect, requiring their numbers to be cleared every few months. These creatures are completely upsetting the ecology of the harbour and are spreading very rapidly. The whole bottom of the harbour at some times is covered by these starfish. Algal blooms occur from time to time in parts of Tasmanian waters and can also be attributed to the release of ballast water.

Another interesting point that came out of the review is the imbalance between animal and plant sectors with respect to quarantine. The executive summary says that the examinations of incursions into Australia over the last 25 years reveal that the rate of incursions of plant pests and diseases was about 10 times more than that for animals. The review has sought a higher status for the plant industries, and rightfully so.

There are also queries about the way risk analysis is conducted, and a suggestion that there is a lack of confidence in the process. Of course there is. There is a real lack of confidence in the process and it is becoming more and more so. Still, Australia has been able to remain relatively free of many of the major pests and diseases of animals and plants, despite much more mobility of the population and an increase in trade. But there are other problems related to our quarantine regulations and international trade that have surfaced.

BREAK.PARA: It was with great concern and worry that I heard of the first appearance of fireblight on the various plants in the botanical gardens in Melbourne. I believe the cotoneaster that was mentioned is of great concern to Tasmanian apple and pear growers. To add insult to injury, this professor who was holidaying from New Zealand just happened to be a scientist—of course—who was able to come and pop into the botanical gardens. He was evidently on a holiday for 2½ days. I always find those things a little difficult to accept on face value. I would like to know who paid for that holiday and if he does this on a regular basis, just dropping into other countries for 2½‐day holidays. His just going into the botanical gardens at that time and finding evidence is difficult for me to accept, along with other things that have come to light post that. The evidence was not assessed here; it was assessed back in New Zealand. It certainly left our boffins rather upset that no‐one had approached them and that people had the hide then to do the same thing in Adelaide.

What these people are doing, basically, is trying to prove a point and say that we have had this disease in this country. What they are doing is a pretty shabby way of acting. There is consultation; we are in mutual trade relations. I just put this down to be a terrible experience and I think New Zealand should be very ashamed of this exercise. New Zealand should also be seeking, and is seeking, to export to Asia, and should not be trying to interfere with our domestic market. Yet it is trying to have a dig at us all the way down the track. I do not think this is doing the relationship between our two countries any good at all.

It is certainly going to cost us money, particularly in my industry in Tasmania, where we developed the fuji apple. It has been developed for the demand in the Japanese market. The Australian yesterday had an article which to me was very timely, saying that the new apple was to generate exports up to about 10,000 tonnes within a decade. Now the Japanese officials are hedging. They are saying that they need more information about the origins of the disease that has been found. They acknowledge that there are no links between Victoria and Tasmania, but they want a survey. So they are starting to survey. It is holding up our apples and it is holding up our opportunities. I find that very concerning, because it was all started by another country that is in competition with us on the Japanese market.

I was speaking only recently to the executive officer of the apple and pear growers in Tasmania, who was briefing me on the enormous amount of effort and dedication that has been put into seeking Asian markets for these specially grown apples. The growers and the exporters are out there doing what they can in putting this together, but then they are having these sorts of issues dropped onto them.

There needs to be a stronger response. I was very disappointed with the minister's response. I thought he should have been much stronger in what he was saying, when this is another blow to our markets. I believe that we are not to the bottom of this issue yet. I think there is a lot more to be said and a lot more to be done about it.
Debate (on motion by Mr Vaile) adjourned.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Bribery in the Sport of Boxing

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government, upon notice, on 13 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to reports on the Nine Network's Sunday program in 1996 concerning bribery in the sport of boxing.
(2) Has his attention been drawn to the role of Mr Arthur Tunstall in Australian boxing.
(3) Is he able to advise what steps are being taken by Mr Tunstall and the Commonwealth Games Association to investigate the claims made on the Sunday program.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Sport, Territories and Local Government; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of the reports on the Nine Network's Sunday program during 1996 concerning allegations of bribery in the sport of boxing at the Seoul Olympic Games in 1988.

(2) I am also aware that Mr Arthur Tunstall is the long standing Secretary-General of the Amateur Boxing Union of Australia (ABUA) and a Vice President of the International Amateur Boxing Association (AIBA).
(3) The Australian Commonwealth Games Association, in which Mr Tunstall holds the position of Secretary/Treasurer, does not have any role in this matter.

Any accusations regarding bribery within the sport of boxing at an international level are a matter for the AIBA and, if they relate to the Olympic Games, the International Olympic Committee. I am advised that the AIBA has initiated an investigation into the bribery claims.
